title: Multi-animal tracking is poor: looking for improvement or advice on better approaches

labels.name: howtousedlc
labels.description: issue regarding the use of DeepLabCut

labels.name: WORK IN PROGRESS!
labels.description: developers are currently working on this feature... stay tuned.

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I've trained DLC resnet50 and resnet152 on 425 images of 4 gerbils in a home cage.  The features tracked were nose, head and tail for the 4 animals (plus 6 wooden blocks in the cage).  The results are not very good (even slightly worse for resnet152). Here's the link to the video:

https://www.dropbox.com/s/fnxz0q8dhoctqey/2020-3-14_09_resnet50_SmallSquare_resnet152_LargeSquare.avi?dl=0

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Is there something else I can do to improve these results aside from adding several hundred more training images?  Should I not track the wooden blocks in the cage (not visualized here)? Does that make things worse for tracking the moving animals?

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I've tried training using resnet152, but the result is somewhat worse than resnet50.

**Additional context**
In the video the smaller square is resnet50 and the larger is resnet152.  The squares are slightly shifted for visualization purpose (and we only show them for likelihood > 0.9).  The colors are 3 features per each animal (nose, head, tail) and each animal has a distinct color. As you can see there are multiple kinds of errors including: both networks continue to mix labels from other animals; the tail is a challenging feature to track; and there are periods where isolated / well visible animals aren't labeled at all (e.g. 1min22sec region where there's a pup just walking around).

Thanks so much for your help.
